title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: rbrsa package facilitates programmatic access Turkish banking sector data Turkish Banking Regulation Supervision Agency (BRSA, known BDDK Turkish). package provides R users clean interface fetch monthly quarterly banking statistics, financial reports, sectoral indicators directly BRSA’s official APIs. vignette demonstrates complete workflow: discovering available data fetching performing basic analysis. key features - Direct API access BRSA monthly bulletins (17 financial tables) - Quarterly Finturk data city-level granularity (7 tables, 82 cities including ‘HEPSİ’ cities) - Consistent parameter interface data sources - Built-metadata tables, banking groups, cities - Multiple export formats: RDS, CSV, Excel via save_data() - Returns base R data frames ready analysis

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: Unlike configuration-heavy approaches, bddkR (based bddkdata, Python package), rbrsa uses programmatic design dynamically extracts column structures API responses maintaining stable user interface. approach reduces maintenance burden adapts BRSA API changes. Related Packages: - bddkR (R): Uses manual configuration translations column mappings - bddk (Python): Provides similar functionality Python users - bddkdata (Python): Provides similar functionality Python/pandas users - pybrsa (Python, forthcoming): Python companion package consistent API

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
code: # Install from CRAN install.packages("rbrsa")  # Or install the development version from GitHub # install.packages("pak") pak.::pkg_install("obakis/rbrsa") # Load the package library(rbrsa)

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: requesting data, ’s useful explore tables banking groups available BDDK’s two main portals. portals official sources, organize data differently: Monthly Bulletin Portal provides high-level, summary reports designed general consumption quick overviews monthly trends without geographic coverage. Finturk Data System provides granular, detailed data, including statistics broken province, whereas standard Monthly Bulletin offers national-level aggregates. Important note: Currently, single grup_kod can specified per request. underlying BDDK API supports multiple grup_kod codes, functionality added future version.

previous_headings: Introduction to the rbrsa package > Part 1: Discovering Available Data
title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: Monthly Bulletin provides high-level, national aggregate statistics.
code: # List available tables in the Monthly Bulletin bulletin_tables <- list_tables("bddk", lang="en") #>  #> Available tables for bddk data: #>  Table_No                            Title #>         1                    Balance Sheet #>         2                  Profit and Loss #>         3                            Loans #>         4                   Consumer Loans #>         5       Sectoral Loan Distribution #>         6                        SME Loans #>         7 Syndication Securitization Loans #>         8                       Securities #>         9                 Deposits by Type #>        10             Deposits by Maturity #>        11               Liquidity Position #>        12                 Capital Adequacy #>        13        Foreign Currency Position #>        14   Off-Balance Sheet Transactions #>        15                           Ratios #>        16                Other Information #>        17            Foreign Branch Ratios head(bulletin_tables) #>   Table_No                      Title #> 1        1              Balance Sheet #> 2        2            Profit and Loss #> 3        3                      Loans #> 4        4             Consumer Loans #> 5        5 Sectoral Loan Distribution #> 6        6                  SME Loans  # List available banking groups for the Monthly Bulletin bulletin_groups <- list_groups("bddk", lang="en") #>  #> Available banking groups for bddk data: #>  Group_Code                             Name #>       10001                     Sector Total #>       10002                    Deposit Banks #>       10008       Deposit - Domestic Private #>       10009                 Deposit - Public #>       10010                Deposit - Foreign #>       10003              Participation Banks #>       10004 Development and Investment Banks #>       10005           Domestic Private Banks #>       10006                     Public Banks #>       10007                    Foreign Banks head(bulletin_groups) #>   Group_Code                       Name #> 1      10001               Sector Total #> 2      10002              Deposit Banks #> 3      10008 Deposit - Domestic Private #> 4      10009           Deposit - Public #> 5      10010          Deposit - Foreign #> 6      10003        Participation Banks

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: Finturk system provides granular data, including provincial breakdowns.
code: # List available tables in Finturk finturk_tables <- list_tables("finturk", lang="en") #>  #> Available tables for finturk data: #>  Table_No                                        Title #>         1                          Loans (Thousand TL) #>         2                       Deposits (Thousand TL) #>         3                 Retail Banking (Thousand TL) #>         4        Selected Sectoral Loans (Thousand TL) #>         5                                   Ratios (%) #>         6 Branches and Distribution by Population (TL) #>         7   Gold Loans and Gold Deposits (Thousand TL) finturk_tables #>   Table_No                                        Title #> 1        1                          Loans (Thousand TL) #> 2        2                       Deposits (Thousand TL) #> 3        3                 Retail Banking (Thousand TL) #> 4        4        Selected Sectoral Loans (Thousand TL) #> 5        5                                   Ratios (%) #> 6        6 Branches and Distribution by Population (TL) #> 7        7   Gold Loans and Gold Deposits (Thousand TL)  # List available banking groups for Finturk finturk_groups <- list_groups("finturk", lang="en") #>  #> Available banking groups for finturk data: #>  Group_Code                             Name #>       10001                     Sector Total #>       10002                    Deposit Banks #>       10003 Development and Investment Banks #>       10004              Participation Banks #>       10005                    Foreign Banks #>       10006                     Public Banks #>       10007  10003 Development and Investment Banks #> 4      10004              Participation Banks #> 5      10005                    Foreign Banks #> 6      10006                     Public Banks #> 7      10007           Domestic Private Banks  # List of cities for Finturk cities <- list_cities() #>  #> Available cities for Finturk quarterly data: #> (Use plate number in fetch_finturk functions) #>   Plaka 0 = HEPSI (All Cities) #>  plaka             il #>      0          HEPSİ #>      1          ADANA #>      2       ADIYAMAN #>      3 AFYONKARAHİSAR #>      4           AĞRI #>      5         AMASYA #>      6         ANKARA #>      7        ANTALYA #>      8         ARTVİN #>      9          AYDIN #>     10      BALIKESİR #>     11        BİLECİK #>     12         BİNGÖL #>     13         BİTLİS #>     14           BOLU #>     15         BURDUR #>     16          BURSA #>     17      ÇANAKKALE #>     18        ÇANKIRI #>     19          ÇORUM #>     20        DENİZLİ #>     21     DİYARBAKIR #>     22         EDİRNE #>     23         ELAZIĞ #>     24       ERZİNCAN #>     25        ERZURUM #>     26      ESKİŞEHİR #>     27      GAZİANTEP #>     28        GİRESUN #>     29      GÜMÜŞHANE #>     30        HAKKARİ #>     31          HATAY #>     32        ISPARTA #>     33         MERSİN #>     34       İSTANBUL #>     35          İZMİR #>     36           KARS #>     37      KASTAMONU #>     38        KAYSERİ #>     39     KIRKLARELİ #>     40       KIRŞEHİR #>     41        KOCAELİ #>     42          KONYA #>     43        KÜTAHYA #>     44        MALATYA #>     45 2     1          ADANA #> 3     2       ADIYAMAN #> 4     3 AFYONKARAHİSAR #> 5     4           AĞRI #> 6     5         AMASYA

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: Let’s fetch “Table 4: Consumer Loans” public banks (grup_kod = 10006) January 2020 December 2020. Let’s compare “Consumer Loans - Housing” “Consumer Loans - Personal Finance” time.
code: my_dat <- fetch_bddk(   start_year = 2020,   start_month = 1,   end_year = 2020,   end_month = 12,   table_no = 4,   grup_kod = 10001,   verbose=TRUE ) #> Fetching table 4 for 12 months: 2020-01 to 2020-12 #> [1/12] 2020-01... 41 rows #> [2/12] 2020-02... 41 rows #> [3/12] 2020-03... 41 rows #> [4/12] 2020-04... 41 rows #> [5/12] 2020-05... 41 rows #> [6/12] 2020-06... 41 rows #> [7/12] 2020-07... 41 rows #> [8/12] 2020-08... 41 rows #> [9/12] 2020-09... 41 rows #> [10/12] 2020-10... 41 rows #> [11/12] 2020-11... 41 rows #> [12/12] 2020-12... 41 rows # Examine the structure of the returned data cat("Dimensions:", dim(my_dat), "\n") #> Dimensions: 492 9 colnames(my_dat) #> [1] "BankaAdi"  "BasitSira" "Ad"        "TRY"       "FX"        "Total"     #> [7] "period"    "currency"  "grup_kod" head(my_dat) #>         BankaAdi BasitSira                                    Ad    TRY FX #> 1 Banking Sector         1                Consumer Loans (2+3+4) 480482 82 #> 2 Banking Sector         2              Consumer Loans - Housing 202648 46 #> 3 Banking Sector         3              Consumer Loans - Vehicle   6979  0 #> 4 Banking Sector         4     Consumer Loans - Personal Finance 270855 36 #> 5 Banking Sector         5   Consumer Loans - Fx Indexed (6+7+8)     65  0 #> 6 Banking Sector         6 Consumer Loans - Housing (Fx Indexed)     55  0 #>    Total  period currency grup_kod #> 1 480564 2020-01       TL    10001 #> 2 202694 2020-01       TL    10001 #> 3   6979 2020-01       TL    10001 #> 4 270892 2020-01       TL    10001 #> 5     65 2020-01       TL    10001 #> 6     55 2020-01       TL    10001 ## To save the results: # temp_file <- tempfile() # filename should be without extension # save_data(my_dat, temp_file, format = "csv") library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)  colnames(my_dat) #> [1] "BankaAdi"  "BasitSira" "Ad"        "TRY"       "FX"        "Total"     #> [7] "period"    "currency"  "grup_kod" cols = c("Consumer Loans - Housing","Consumer Loans - Personal Finance") p = my_dat |>   select(Ad,TRY,period) |>   filter(Ad %in% cols) |>   mutate(date=as.Date(paste0(period, "-01"))) |>   ggplot(aes(x=date, y=TRY, color=Ad, group=Ad, shape=Ad)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   geom_point(size = 2.4, alpha = 0.7) +   scale_x_date(     date_breaks = "2 months",      # Show tick every 3 months     date_labels = "%b %Y",         # Format as "Jan 2020"     expand = c(0.01, 0)           # Reduce padding   ) +   scale_y_continuous(     labels = scales::comma       # Format numbers with commas   ) +   labs(     title = "Consumer Loans Trend, Jan 2020-Dec 2020 (TRY)",     subtitle = "Monthly data for Housing vs Personal Finance loans",     x = "",     y = ""   ) +   theme_minimal() + theme(     legend.position = "bottom",  # This moves the legend to the bottom     axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),     plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 14),   ) p

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: Now let’s explore detailed Finturk data. ’ll fetch “Table 2: Deposits” banks (grup_kod = 10001), provinces 2023 2024. Finturk data includes province column (il). Let’s examine share selected provinces total deposits ove 2020-2024 period.
code: my_dat2 <- fetch_finturk(   start_year = 2023,   start_month = 3,   end_year = 2024,   end_month = 12,   table_no = 2,   grup_kod = 10001,   il=0,   verbose=FALSE ) # Examine the structure of the returned data cat("Dimensions:", dim(my_dat2), "\n") #> Dimensions: 656 15 colnames(my_dat2) #>  [1] "Yıl"                     "Ay"                      #>  [3] "Şehir"                   "Grup"                    #>  [5] "Tasarruf Mevduatı"       "Tasarruf Mevduatı (TL)"  #>  [7] "Tasarruf Mevduatı (DTH)" "Diğer Mevduat"           #>  [9] "Diğer Mevduat (TL)"      "Diğer Mevduat (DTH)"     #> [11] "Toplam Mevduat"          "period"                  #> [13] "grup_kod"                "il"                      #> [15] "table_no" head(my_dat2) #>    Yıl Ay          Şehir   Grup Tasarruf Mevduatı Tasarruf Mevduatı (TL) #> 1 2023  3          ADANA SEKTÖR         101555827               68165445 #> 2 2023  3       ADIYAMAN SEKTÖR          14189512                8769470 #> 3 2023  3 AFYONKARAHİSAR SEKTÖR          26182581               13630002 #> 4 2023  3           AĞRI SEKTÖR           4541209                2860903 #> 5 2023  3        AKSARAY SEKTÖR          22535449               10411079 #> 6 2023  3         AMASYA SEKTÖR           9456856                5505734 #>   Tasarruf Mevduatı (DTH) Diğer Mevduat Diğer Mevduat (TL) Diğer Mevduat (DTH) #> 1                33390382      40948954           29321746            11627208 #> 2                 5420042       4133270            3422143              711127 #> 3                12552579       7218373            5476164             1742209 #> 4                 1680306       1495488            1246086              249402 #> 5                12124370       4662855            3259852             1403003 #> 6                 3951122       1956146            1588133              368013 #>   Toplam Mevduat  period grup_kod il table_no #> 1      142504781 2023-03    10001  0        2 #> 2       18322782 2023-03    10001  0        2 #> 3       33400954 2023-03    10001  0        2 #> 4        6036697 2023-03    10001  0        2 #> 5       27198304 2023-03    10001  0        2 #> 6       11413002 2023-03    10001  0        2 ## To save the results: # temp_file <- tempfile() # filename should be without extension # save_data(my_dat, temp_file, format = "csv") sel_cities =c("ADANA","MALATYA","MUĞLA","KAYSERİ") cols = c("Şehir", "period","Toplam Mevduat") lookup <- c(city="Şehir", deposit="Toplam Mevduat") p2 = my_dat2[,cols] |>   rename(all_of(lookup)) |>   mutate(date=as.Date(paste0(period, "-01"))) |>   mutate(.by=period, sh = 100*deposit/sum(deposit, na.rm=TRUE)) |>   filter( city %in% sel_cities) |>     ggplot(aes(x=date, y=sh, color=city, group=city, shape=city)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   geom_point(size = 2.4, alpha = 0.7) +   scale_x_date(     date_breaks = "3 months",      # Show tick every 3 months     date_labels = "%b %Y",         # Format as "Jan 2020"     expand = c(0.01, 0)           # Reduce padding   ) +   labs(     title = "Share of Selected Cities in Deposits, 2020-2023 (TRY)",     x = "",     y = ""   ) +   theme_minimal() + theme(     legend.position = "bottom",  # This moves the legend to the bottom     axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),     plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 14),   ) p2

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: save_data() function allows export results various formats use tools.
code: # Save to different formats. file name must be without extension save_data(my_dat, "filename_you_prefer", format = "csv") save_data(my_dat, "filename_you_prefer", format = "rds") save_data(my_dat, "filename_you_prefer", format = "xlsx")  # Using tempfile() for examples (as in README) temp_file <- tempfile() save_data(my_dat, temp_file, format = "csv") cat("Data saved to:", temp_file, "\n")

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: vignette demonstrated basic workflow rbrs package. learn : Explore functions package reference: https://obakis.github.io/rbrsa/reference/ Try different tables banking groups using list_tables() list_groups(). Check pybrsa package (https://github.com/obakis/pybrsa) similar functionality Python. (CONSTRUCTION)

title: Getting Started with Turkish Banking Data
text: Currently, single grup_kod province can specified per request. underlying BDDK API supports multiple grup_kods provinces, functionality added future version rbrsa. detailed function references advanced usage, visit complete package documentation https://obakis.github.io/rbrsa/

what: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from BRSA (BDDK)
title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from BRSA (BDDK)
text: R package programmatic access Turkish banking sector data Turkish Banking Regulation Supervision Agency (BRSA, known BDDK Turkish). package provides R users clean interface fetch monthly quarterly banking statistics, financial reports, sectoral indicators directly BRSA’s official APIs.

title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from BRSA (BDDK)
text: Direct API access BRSA monthly bulletins (17 financial tables) Quarterly Finturk data city-level granularity (7 tables, 82 cities including ‘HEPSİ’ cities) Consistent parameter interface data sources Built-metadata tables, banking groups, cities Multiple export formats: RDS, CSV, Excel via save_data() Returns base R data frames ready analysis

title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from BRSA (BDDK)
text: Lightweight Authentic: packages providing access BDDK data (like bddkR) also fetch data programmatically, add heavy translation layer—maintaining manual configuration files map Turkish column names categorical values English. provides user convenience high maintenance cost. rbrsa takes different path. interacts directly API uses data returns minimal alteration: * Monthly Bulletin, uses official English column names labels provided API lang = "en" set. * Finturk dataset, API provides data Turkish, returns authentic Turkish names. deliberate choice. avoiding separate translation system, rbrsa eliminates major maintenance burden, instantly adapts API changes, guarantees data see exactly official source provides.

title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from BRSA (BDDK)
text: bddkR (R): Uses manual configuration translations column mappings bddk (Python): Provides similar functionality Python users bddkdata (Python): Provides similar functionality Python/pandas users pybrsa (Python, forthcoming): Python companion package consistent API

title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from BRSA (BDDK)
text: can install CRAN development version can installed GitHub:
code: install.packages("rbrsa") #install.packages("pak") pak::pkg_install("obakis/rbrsa")

title: Fetch Turkish Banking Sector Data from BRSA (BDDK)
text: Full package documentation function references available : https://obakis.github.io/rbrsa/ rbrsa package retrieves tables two distinct publication portals maintained Turkish Banking Regulation Supervision Agency (BDDK). portals official sources, organize data differently: Monthly Bulletin Portal provides high-level, summary reports designed general consumption quick overviews monthly trends without geographic coverage. Finturk Data System provides granular, detailed data, including statistics broken province, whereas standard Monthly Bulletin offers national-level aggregates. Note: Currently, single grup_kod can specified per request. underlying BDDK API supports multiple grup_kod codes, functionality added future version.
code: library(rbrsa) ## Explore available tables list_tables("bddk") # list_tables("bddk","tr") list_tables("finturk")  # list_tables("finturk", "tr") list_groups("bddk")   list_groups("bddk","tr")   list_groups("finturk")  ## Monthly data (Table 15: Ratios) data <- fetch_bddk(2024, 1, 2024, 3, table_no = 15, grup_kod = 10001)  ## Quarterly Finturk data q_data <- fetch_finturk(2024, 3, 2024, 9, table_no = 1, grup_kod = 10007)  ## Save results temp_file <- tempfile() # filename should be without extension save_data(q_data, temp_file, format = "csv")

what: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk
title: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk
text: Fetches BDDK data range months calling fetch_bddk1 iteratively.

title: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk
code: fetch_bddk(   start_year,   start_month,   end_year,   end_month,   table_no,   grup_kod = 10001,   currency = "TL",   lang = "en",   delay = 0.5,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk
text: start_year, end_year Starting/ending year (YYYY). start_month, end_month Starting/ending month (1-12). table_no Table number fetch (1-17). default. Use list_tables source = "bddk" see available options. grup_kod Group code (10001-10016). Default 10001. Use list_groups source = "bddk" see available options. currency Currency code ("TL" "USD"). Default "TL". lang Language ("en" "tr"). Default "en". delay Delay requests seconds. Default 0.5. verbose Print progress messages. Default TRUE.

title: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk
text: Combined data frame "fetch_info" attribute.

title: Fetch multiple period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk
code: # \donttest{   # Fetch multiple months   my_dat <- fetch_bddk(2024, 1, 2024, 3, table_no = 15) #> Fetching table 15 for 3 months: 2024-01 to 2024-03 #> [1/3] 2024-01... 32 rows #> [2/3] 2024-02... 32 rows #> [3/3] 2024-03... 32 rows # }

what: Fetch single period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk1
title: Fetch single period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk1
text: Retrieves data specific table, month, grup_kod BDDK Monthly Bulletin.

title: Fetch single period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk1
code: fetch_bddk1(   year,   month,   table_no,   grup_kod = 10001,   currency = "TL",   lang = "en" )

title: Fetch single period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk1
text: year Year 4-digit integer (YYYY). month Month integer (1-12). table_no Table number fetch (1-17). default. Use list_tables source = "bddk" see available options. grup_kod Group code (10001-10010). Default 10001. Use list_groups source = "bddk" see available options. currency Currency code ("TL" "USD"). Default "TL". lang Language ("en" "tr"). Default "en".

title: Fetch single period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk1
text: Data frame data period/currency metadata.

title: Fetch single period table from BDDK website — fetch_bddk1
code: # \donttest{   # Fetch Table 15 (Ratios) for January 2024   data <- fetch_bddk1(2024, 1, 15) # }

what: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
title: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
text: Fetches Finturk data range quarters calling fetch_finturk1 iteratively.

title: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
code: fetch_finturk(   start_year,   start_month,   end_year,   end_month,   table_no,   grup_kod = 10001,   il = 0,   delay = 0.5,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
text: start_year, end_year Starting/ending year (YYYY). start_month, end_month Starting/ending month (3,6,9,12). table_no Table number fetch (1-7). default. Use list_tables source = "finturk" see available options. grup_kod Group code (10001-10007). Default 10001. Use list_groups source = "finturk" see available options. il plaka (license plate) number (0-81, 99). Default 0. delay Delay requests seconds. Default 0.5. verbose Print progress messages. Default TRUE.

title: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
text: Combined data frame "fetch_info" attribute.

title: Fetch multiple period Finturk data — fetch_finturk
code: # \donttest{   # Fetch multiple quarters   my_data <- fetch_finturk(2024, 3, 2024, 9, table_no = 1) #> Fetching table 1 for 3 quarterly periods: 2024-03 to 2024-09 #> [1/3] 2024-03... 82 rows #> [2/3] 2024-06... 82 rows #> [3/3] 2024-09... 82 rows # }

what: Fetch single period Finturk data — fetch_finturk1
title: Fetch single period Finturk data — fetch_finturk1
text: Retrieves quarterly data BDDK Finturk website

title: Fetch single period Finturk data — fetch_finturk1
code: fetch_finturk1(year, month, table_no, grup_kod = 10001, il = 0)

title: Fetch single period Finturk data — fetch_finturk1
text: year Year 4-digit integer (YYYY). month Month integer (3,6,9,12 quarterly data). table_no Table number fetch (1-7). default. grup_kod Group code (10001-1007). Default 10001. il plaka (license plate) number (0-81, 99). Default 0. 0=HEPSİ (Cities), 1=Adana, 6=Ankara, 34=İstanbul, 35=İzmir, etc. See list_cities full list.

title: Fetch single period Finturk data — fetch_finturk1
text: Data frame data period metadata.

title: Fetch single period Finturk data — fetch_finturk1
code: # \donttest{   # Fetch Table 1 (Loans) for Q1 2024   data <- fetch_finturk1(2024, 3, 1) # }

what: List Available Cities for Finturk Print available cities for Finturk quarterly data with plaka (license plate) numbers. — list_cities
title: List Available Cities for Finturk Print available cities for Finturk quarterly data with plaka (license plate) numbers. — list_cities

what: List available groups Print available banking groups for a data source. — list_groups
title: List available groups Print available banking groups for a data source. — list_groups
text: List available groups Print available banking groups data source.

title: List available groups Print available banking groups for a data source. — list_groups
code: list_groups(source = c("bddk", "finturk"), lang = c("en", "tr"))

title: List available groups Print available banking groups for a data source. — list_groups
text: source Either "bddk" "finturk" lang Either "tr" "en" names. "en" default

title: List available groups Print available banking groups for a data source. — list_groups
text: Data frame available groups (invisibly)

title: List available groups Print available banking groups for a data source. — list_groups
code: list_groups("bddk") #>  #> Available banking groups for bddk data: #>  Group_Code                             Name #>       10001                     Sector Total #>       10002                    Deposit Banks #>       10008       Deposit - Domestic Private #>       10009                 Deposit - Public #>       10010                Deposit - Foreign #>       10003              Participation Banks #>       10004 Development and Investment Banks #>       10005           Domestic Private Banks #>       10006                     Public Banks #>       10007                    Foreign Banks list_groups("finturk","tr") #>  #> Available banking groups for finturk data: #>  Group_Code                Name #>       10001              SEKTÖR #>       10002             MEVDUAT #>       10003 KALKINMA VE YATIRIM #>       10004             KATILIM #>       10005             YABANCI #>       10006                KAMU #>       10007          YERLİ ÖZEL

title: List Available Tables Print available tables for a data source. — list_tables
code: list_tables("bddk") #>  #> Available tables for bddk data: #>  Table_No                            Title #>         1                    Balance Sheet #>         2                  Profit and Loss #>         3                            Loans #>         4                   Consumer Loans #>         5       Sectoral Loan Distribution #>         6                        SME Loans #>         7 Syndication Securitization Loans #>         8                       Securities #>         9                 Deposits by Type #>        10             Deposits by Maturity #>        11               Liquidity Position #>        12                 Capital Adequacy #>        13        Foreign Currency Position #>        14   Off-Balance Sheet Transactions #>        15                           Ratios #>        16                Other Information #>        17            Foreign Branch Ratios list_tables("finturk", "tr") #>  #> Available tables for finturk data: #>  Table_No                                      Title #>         1                          Krediler (Bin TL) #>         2                           Mevduat (Bin TL) #>         3               Bireysel Bankacılık (Bin TL) #>         4        Seçilmiş Sektörel Krediler (Bin TL) #>         5                                Oranlar (%) #>         6 Şubeler (Adet) ve Nüfusa Göre Dağılım (TL) #>         7 Altın Kredileri ve Altın Mevduatı (Bin TL)

what: Convert plaka (license plate number) to province name Maps Turkish license plate numbers to province names used in the Finturk API. — plaka_to_city
title: Convert plaka (license plate number) to province name Maps Turkish license plate numbers to province names used in the Finturk API. — plaka_to_city
text: Convert plaka (license plate number)  province name Maps Turkish license plate numbers province names used Finturk API.

title: Convert plaka (license plate number) to province name Maps Turkish license plate numbers to province names used in the Finturk API. — plaka_to_city
code: plaka_to_city(plaka)

title: Convert plaka (license plate number) to province name Maps Turkish license plate numbers to province names used in the Finturk API. — plaka_to_city
text: plaka license plate number (0 "HEPSI", 1-81 provinces, 999 "YURT DISI")

title: Convert plaka (license plate number) to province name Maps Turkish license plate numbers to province names used in the Finturk API. — plaka_to_city
text: province name CAPS required API

title: Convert plaka (license plate number) to province name Maps Turkish license plate numbers to province names used in the Finturk API. — plaka_to_city
code: plaka_to_city(6)   # "ANKARA" #> [1] "ANKARA" plaka_to_city(34)  # "ISTANBUL" #> [1] "İSTANBUL" plaka_to_city(0)   # "HEPSI" #> [1] "HEPSİ"

what: Save Fetched Data to Multiple Formats — save_data
title: Save Fetched Data to Multiple Formats — save_data
text: Save Fetched Data Multiple Formats

title: Save Fetched Data to Multiple Formats — save_data
code: save_data(df, filename = NULL, format = "rds")

title: Save Fetched Data to Multiple Formats — save_data
text: df Data frame save (fetch_info attribute auto-naming). filename Base name output file (without extension). format Output format: "rds", "csv", "xlsx". Default "rds".

title: Save Fetched Data to Multiple Formats — save_data
text: Full file path (invisibly).

title: Save Fetched Data to Multiple Formats — save_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   my_data <- fetch_bddk1(2024, 1, 15)   temp_file <- tempfile() # filename should be without extension   save_data(my_data, temp_file, format = "csv") } # }

title: rbrsa 0.1.0
text: Initial release core functionality Support 17 monthly BRSA tables Support 7 quarterly Finturk tables Built-metadata tables, groups, cities Export functions RDS, CSV, Excel formats
